issue.body:
Title.

It seems like the vorbis implementation has been somewhat buggy for some time.

After opening an ogg stream and reading its header information with `ov_info()`, in certain cases (certain files) the internal stream read position isn't properly reset back to the beginning. This causes a subsequent call to `ov_pcm_total()` to return a wrong total sample count. Reading in sample data using `ov_read()` based on this incorrect sample count will then return less samples than what was reported leading to the entire file failing to load. Explicitly resetting the stream read position back to the beginning of the file using `ov_raw_seek()` after calling `ov_info()` seems to work around this problem.

Assuming that this bug will realistically never get fixed, I don't have any reservations about building in this workaround. Glancing over the vorbis issue tracker it is unlikely most reported bugs will ever get fixed.

All the information necessary to reproduce the bug and test this fix can be found in #3578.

Fixes #3578

body:
SFML's audio implementation was rewritten for SFML 3. One of the many things that changed is that we don't use our own hand-rolled wav decoder any more. Since we are already using miniaudio for audio processing, we also use its decoders to perform decoding for us for the formats that it supports of which wav is one. The miniaudio wav decoder provides much better support for more formats than our hand-rolled implementation in SFML 2. I had no issue playing both wav files you provided with SFML 3.

Regarding the ogg file: I could reproduce the bug in SFML 3. It turns out it is caused by the somewhat buggy vorbis reference implementation that we use for ogg decoding. A workaround has been provided in #3579, with it I can play both ogg files correctly using SFML 3. Feel free to give it a try.

I confirm that the wav files already work with sfml 3.0.0, I probably mixed my tests when going back-and-forth between versions, sorry for that.

I just tested the ogg workaround on the PR and I confirm it works on my setup too, thank you for your quick answer !

Do you intend to backport this change in smfl 2.6.x, or will you stick to smfl 3.x ?

While the ogg fix could theoretically be backported, it wouldn't help you much because the wav implementation would still stay broken. Because the current wav decoding is provided by miniaudio (which was introduced in SFML 3) it cannot be backported to 2.x.

The wav files were used for tests, we are sticking to ogg files for the project (we first had the ogg bug and tried wav instead, that's how we found those cases).
Since we found a way to generate ogg files that can run with the current 2.6.2, I should not need the fix for now, unless it appears again despite our new export pipeline. I can fork with the fix if the need arises, so it's mostly for other people still using the 2.x branch.

(For the record, I am sticking with sfml 2.x for this project since I am getting closer to a release, migrating the whole engine on 3.x at this point feels risky and time-consuming)
I guess the OGG fix is simple enough to be backported, in case anyone wants to provide PR against the `2.6.x` branch

## How to test this PR?

The test case is similar to the one provided in issue #3578 but only concerns the ogg files provided.

```cpp
#include <SFML/Audio.hpp>

int main()
{
    std::string path_Ogg_NotWorking = "audio-test-files/Sample_Ogg_NotWorking.ogg";
    std::string path_Ogg_Working = "audio-test-files/Sample_Ogg_Working.ogg";

    sf::SoundBuffer buffer_Ogg_NotWorking;
    sf::SoundBuffer buffer_Ogg_Working;

    bool result_Ogg_NotWorking = buffer_Ogg_NotWorking.loadFromFile(path_Ogg_NotWorking);
    bool result_Ogg_Working = buffer_Ogg_Working.loadFromFile(path_Ogg_Working);
}
```
